title: Snooker news: David Gilbert reacts to 'Mark Selby masterclass' after English Open walloping
text:
David Gilbert ran into Mark Selby at his best in Crawley (Picture: Getty Images)

David Gilbert had no complaints after being shown an ‘absolute Mark Selby masterclass’ in a 9-1 thrashing in the English Open final.

Selby made short work of the world number 11 in Crawley, finishing with a pot success rate of 97% as he rolled in two centuries and six more half-centuries.

There was little that Gilbert could do about the stunning performance from the Jester from Leicester, with the only frame he got on the board coming from a 101 break.

The World Championship semi-finalist is still searching for his first major title having fallen short in four ranking finals, and admits his game still needs tightening up.

‘It was an absolute Selby masterclass,’ said Gilbert after the defeat in West Sussex. ‘He does that all the time against me in practice so I’ve seen it before, I just hoped he wasn’t going to do it today.

‘Another brilliant week for me, another final. Who knows whether it will happen or not [winning a title], I’m still quite weak in areas. Mark’s safety was fantastic today, every time I came to the table I seemed to be snookered or on the top cush.’

One person who is convinced that Gilbert will get his hands on a trophy is Selby who rates the Angry Farmer extremely highly as a player and as a person.

‘To play Dave in the final is an absolute privilege. It’s only a matter of time for him, you can’t be as good as him and not win tournaments, I would expect him to win one this year and then the floodgates will open and he’ll win many more.

‘I’m pleased for myself but gutted for him at the same time because he’s a great, great player and an even better lad off the table.

‘If I wasn’t in the final I’d have been rooting for him or come back up here to support him, that’s how much I like the kid.

‘So, gutted for him, but he keeps knocking on the door, semi-finals of the Worlds, four ranking finals, it’s only a matter of time until he turns that runner-up spot into a win, and when he does do that I think he’ll win a lot more.’

Selby and Gilbert will both be back in action at the World Open which begins on 28 October in Yushan.

That was the scene of Gilbert’s most heartbreaking defeat last year, when he lost the final 10-9 to Mark Williams having led 9-5 against the three-time world champion.
